column1: What is the central question of controllability?
column2: Whether it is possible to steer the state from any initial condition to any final condition using admissible inputs.
column3: Property of the realization, not just the differential equation.

column1: What is the central question of observability?
column2: Whether the internal state can be uniquely reconstructed from knowledge of the input and output over time.

column1: Why are controllability and observability realization properties?
column2: They depend on how the state is represented internally, not only on the input–output map.

column1: What is the controllability matrix?
column3: Used to test reachability via rank.

column1: What is the controllability rank condition?
column2: The realization is controllable iff the controllability matrix has full row rank.

column1: What is the observability matrix?
column3: Used to test reconstructability of the state.

column1: What is the observability rank condition?
column2: The realization is observable iff the observability matrix has full column rank.

column1: What does lack of controllability mean dynamically?
column2: Some state components cannot be influenced by the input.

column1: What does lack of observability mean dynamically?
column2: Some state components do not affect the output.

column1: ⚠️ Why is controllability not the same as stabilizability?
column2: A system may have uncontrollable but stable modes.
column3: These do not affect asymptotic behavior but matter structurally.

column1: What is the duality between controllability and observability?
column2: Controllability of (A,B) is equivalent to observability of (Aᵀ,Cᵀ).
column3: Reveals deep symmetry in the theory.

column1: Why is duality important conceptually?
column2: It allows results to be transferred between controllability and observability.

column1: How do invariant subspaces relate to uncontrollability?
column2: Uncontrollable modes span invariant subspaces of A.
column3: These subspaces cannot be reached by input.

column1: How do invariant subspaces relate to unobservability?
column2: Unobservable modes lie in invariant subspaces invisible to C.
column3: These subspaces do not affect output.

column1: What is the Kalman decomposition?
column2: A decomposition of the state space into controllable/observable subspaces.

column1: What four subspaces appear in the Kalman decomposition?
column2: Controllable–observable, controllable–unobservable, uncontrollable–observable, uncontrollable–unobservable.

column1: Why is the Kalman decomposition fundamental?
column2: It exposes all structural redundancy in a realization.

column1: How does controllability relate to minimality?
column2: A minimal realization must be controllable.

column1: How does observability relate to minimality?
column2: A minimal realization must be observable.

column1: Why can a transfer function hide uncontrollable modes?
column2: Uncontrollable but stable modes may not appear in the input–output behavior.

column1: Why can a transfer function hide unobservable modes?
column2: Unobservable modes do not affect output.

column1: How can controllability be interpreted in passive networks?
column2: As the ability of external sources to inject energy into all storage elements.

column1: How can observability be interpreted in passive networks?
column2: As the ability to sense stored energy through terminal variables.

column1: ⚠️ Why is uncontrollable energy problematic in synthesis?
column2: It corresponds to isolated or trapped energy storage.

column1: Give an example of an uncontrollable but stable mode.
column2: A decoupled stable subsystem not connected to the input.

column1: Give an example of an unobservable mode.
column2: A state that evolves but does not appear in the output equation.

column1: ⚠️ What is the most common mistake when first learning controllability?
column2: Assuming it is purely an input–output concept.
column3: It is fundamentally a state-space notion.

column1: Why is Chapter 4 a turning point in the book?
column2: It introduces structural criteria that define meaningful realizations.
column3: Sets the stage for minimality and canonical forms.
